content: I and my siblings were pretty much "farmed out" as farm help as soon as we were old enough to pick fruit, haul hay, etc. We got to keep what we earned, but that was about it. I do remember gathering up pop bottles to redeem at the local Rexall Drug store for enough money (25 cents) to go to the matinee at the local movie house, which was next door to it. Most of the time, it was just a matter of picking them up on the way, because back then people threw them in the ditches or left them standing next to their garbage cans. It was not that we were poor, but our parents had come through the Depression, and learning to survive early on was considered a necessary condition. I was driving/operating tractors and such from 8 years old on. Dad bought an old large orchard of 370 trees, and I was expected to do most the work caring for it on a daily basis from that point on - and hated the place. Stolen apples always tasted better than ones you have to grow yerself - - As for our boys, though there was never a regular allowance, we gave them frugally what money they needed in exchange for them doing the yard care and keep their rooms straight. I ran the community swimming pool during the summer, and got them small jobs of working in the concession area and checking-in clothes baskets (before lockers). Eventually, they worked up through pool care to teaching swimming lessons and being lifeguards. As they grew up and moved on to jobs of their on selection, the younger boys replaced them. From the time the boys were old enough to need an allowance, they've pretty much earned what they got. Now, they're all married, moved off, and making double what I ever made - - Time to ask them for an allowance!! Wandering and Wondering

content: My kids get an allowance. I give their age plus 5. My 16 year old, for example, gets 21 dollars every 2 weeks. All three are expected to tithe 10 %, save at least 10%, and the rest is theirs. They also have assigned chores, and failure to do them hits them both in the wallet, and in privileges. I hope to instill in my youngsters that Credit is NOT the way to go, and that the way to purchase almost everything in this world is with CASH. My folks taught me nothing about money, and I paid for it. I want them to at least know what the best path is, then they can decide for themselves when they fly away. content: quote: Originally posted by boughtwaprice: Tried the allowance thing a few times, until they started slacking and thinking they'd still get paid for doing a crappy job. Now they don't get it. I assigned a pay scale for various tasks in the house and watched as my kids decided to do more than the other so they could claim more of the prize. Use a calender and have a list of jobs and what those tasks are worth. If a task is COMPLETED then they got to put their initials on the calender and the task's line number. With more kids you would have chart tasks with days of the week and watch to see whose more interested in making money. This way the one with the motivation makes the money and the one who slacks off get's NADA!!! It takes a little while but they get tired of seeing the other kid's happy face on Payday. I don't know if this would work for every family but it worked for my two kids, who became very competitive and I rarely had to ask for something to get done. content: We had four children. They got a small allowance based on their starting at age 4. $1.00 + $1.00 for each year. 25% to savings. 25% to church, missions or a charity – we had to approve it until age 12 then they selected their own charity. 50% was theirs’ to spend. They got that money no matter what. They were required to help in the home; we used a rotating chore schedule with varying expectations according to their age. They did their at home jobs. Because if, not I got them up at 5 am to do them. I only had to do it once to one of our daughters. Any money the earned went: 25% to savings 10% to church or same as above. 15% to house hold expenses. 50% rest was theirs’ When we paid for their things, we chose them. If they paid for it, it still had to meet family our standards. It was never a problem. The spacing between birthdates was 15 months, 25 months and 6 ½ years. Our daughters, the two oldest kids, came to us when started high school, (They were always in they same grade.) and asked how much money did we think we spent on their clothing and personal things. We said an average of about $10.00 – 15.00 a week average. How about doing this; you give us each $30.00 a week now allowance. We keep the same giving and savings rules on the $30.00 a week and we buy and choose our own personal things. They said, this is a good deal for you and it lets us buy what we want to buy. We said fine, we thought it would last about a month. It lasted the rest of the time they lived at home. They both had summer and weekend jobs. The girls were and still are the best money managers I know. They had about $10,000.00 each in savings when graduated from high school. The boys didn’t become good money managers until they got married.
